name: OpenAPIObject
description: This is the root document object of the OpenAPI document.

properties.name: openapi
properties.desc: REQUIRED. This string MUST be the semantic version number of the OpenAPI Specification version that the OpenAPI document uses. The openapi field SHOULD be used by tooling specifications and clients to interpret the OpenAPI document. This is not related to the API info.version string.

properties.name: info
properties.desc: REQUIRED. Provides metadata about the API. The metadata MAY be used by tooling as required.

properties.name: servers
properties.desc: An array of Server Objects, which provide connectivity information to a target server. If the servers property is not provided, or is an empty array, the default value would be a Server Object with a url value of /.

properties.name: paths
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The available paths and operations for the API.

properties.name: components
properties.desc: An element to hold various schemas for the specification.

properties.name: security
properties.desc: A declaration of which security mechanisms can be used across the API. The list of values includes alternative security requirement objects that can be used. Only one of the security requirement objects need to be satisfied to authorize a request. Individual operations can override this definition. To make security optional, an empty security requirement ({}) can be included in the array.

properties.name: tags
properties.desc: A list of tags used by the specification with additional metadata. The order of the tags can be used to reflect on their order by the parsing tools. Not all tags that are used by the Operation Object must be declared. The tags that are not declared MAY be organized randomly or based on the tools' logic. Each tag name in the list MUST be unique.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation.

name: InfoObject
description:
The object provides metadata about the API.
The metadata MAY be used by the clients if needed, and MAY be presented in editing or documentation generation tools for convenience.

properties.name: title
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The title of the API.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description of the API. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: termsOfService
properties.desc: A URL to the Terms of Service for the API. MUST be in the format of a URL.

properties.name: contact
properties.desc: The contact information for the exposed API.

properties.name: license
properties.desc: The license information for the exposed API.

properties.name: version
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The version of the OpenAPI document (which is distinct from the OpenAPI Specification version or the API implementation version).

name: ContactObject
description: Contact information for the exposed API.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: The identifying name of the contact person/organization.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: The URL pointing to the contact information. MUST be in the format of a URL.

properties.name: email
properties.desc: The email address of the contact person/organization. MUST be in the format of an email address.

name: LicenseObject
description: License information for the exposed API.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The license name used for the API.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: A URL to the license used for the API. MUST be in the format of a URL.

name: ServerObject
description: An object representing a Server.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: REQUIRED. A URL to the target host. This URL supports Server Variables and MAY be relative, to indicate that the host location is relative to the location where the OpenAPI document is being served. Variable substitutions will be made when a variable is named in {brackets}.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: An optional string describing the host designated by the URL. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: variables
properties.desc: A map between a variable name and its value.  The value is used for substitution in the server's URL template.

name: ServerVariableObject
description: An object representing a Server Variable for server URL template substitution.

properties.name: enum
properties.desc: An enumeration of string values to be used if the substitution options are from a limited set. The array SHOULD NOT be empty.

properties.name: default
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The default value to use for substitution, which SHALL be sent if an alternate value is not supplied. Note this behavior is different than the Schema Object's treatment of default values, because in those cases parameter values are optional. If the enum is defined, the value SHOULD exist in the enum's values.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: An optional description for the server variable. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

name: ComponentsObject
description:
Holds a set of reusable objects for different aspects of the OAS.
All objects defined within the components object will have no effect on the API unless they are explicitly referenced from properties outside the components object.

properties.name: schemas
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Schema Objects.

properties.name: responses
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Response Objects.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Parameter Objects.

properties.name: examples
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Example Objects.

properties.name: requestBodies
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Request Body Objects.

properties.name: headers
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Header Objects.

properties.name: securitySchemes
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Security Scheme Objects.

properties.name: links
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Link Objects.

properties.name: callbacks
properties.desc: An object to hold reusable Callback Objects.

name: PathsObject
description: Holds the relative paths to the individual endpoints and their operations. The path is appended to the URL from the Server Object in order to construct the full URL. The Paths MAY be empty, due to ACL constraints.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A relative path to an individual endpoint. The field name MUST begin with a forward slash (/). The path is appended (no relative URL resolution) to the expanded URL from the Server Object's url field in order to construct the full URL. Path templating is allowed. When matching URLs, concrete (non-templated) paths would be matched before their templated counterparts. Templated paths with the same hierarchy but different templated names MUST NOT exist as they are identical. In case of ambiguous matching, it's up to the tooling to decide which one to use.

name: PathItemObject
description: Describes the operations available on a single path. A Path Item MAY be empty, due to ACL constraints. The path itself is still exposed to the documentation viewer but they will not know which operations and parameters are available.

properties.name: $ref
properties.desc: Allows for an external definition of this path item. The referenced structure MUST be in the format of a Path Item Object. In case a Path Item Object field appears both in the defined object and the referenced object, the behavior is undefined.

properties.name: summary
properties.desc: An optional, string summary, intended to apply to all operations in this path.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: An optional, string description, intended to apply to all operations in this path. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: get
properties.desc: A definition of a GET operation on this path.

properties.name: put
properties.desc: A definition of a PUT operation on this path.

properties.name: post
properties.desc: A definition of a POST operation on this path.

properties.name: delete
properties.desc: A definition of a DELETE operation on this path.

properties.name: options
properties.desc: A definition of a OPTIONS operation on this path.

properties.name: head
properties.desc: A definition of a HEAD operation on this path.

properties.name: patch
properties.desc: A definition of a PATCH operation on this path.

properties.name: trace
properties.desc: A definition of a TRACE operation on this path.

properties.name: servers
properties.desc: An alternative server array to service all operations in this path.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: A list of parameters that are applicable for all the operations described under this path. These parameters can be overridden at the operation level, but cannot be removed there. The list MUST NOT include duplicated parameters. A unique parameter is defined by a combination of a name and location. The list can use the Reference Object to link to parameters that are defined at the OpenAPI Object's components/parameters.

name: OperationObject
description: Describes a single API operation on a path.

properties.name: tags
properties.desc: A list of tags for API documentation control. Tags can be used for logical grouping of operations by resources or any other qualifier.

properties.name: summary
properties.desc: A short summary of what the operation does.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A verbose explanation of the operation behavior. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this operation.

properties.name: operationId
properties.desc: Unique string used to identify the operation. The id MUST be unique among all operations described in the API. The operationId value is case-sensitive. Tools and libraries MAY use the operationId to uniquely identify an operation, therefore, it is RECOMMENDED to follow common programming naming conventions.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: A list of parameters that are applicable for this operation. If a parameter is already defined at the Path Item, the new definition will override it but can never remove it. The list MUST NOT include duplicated parameters. A unique parameter is defined by a combination of a name and location. The list can use the Reference Object to link to parameters that are defined at the OpenAPI Object's components/parameters.

properties.name: requestBody
properties.desc: The request body applicable for this operation. The requestBody is only supported in HTTP methods where the HTTP 1.1 specification RFC7231 has explicitly defined semantics for request bodies. In other cases where the HTTP spec is vague, requestBody SHALL be ignored by consumers.

properties.name: responses
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The list of possible responses as they are returned from executing this operation.

properties.name: callbacks
properties.desc: A map of possible out-of band callbacks related to the parent operation. The key is a unique identifier for the Callback Object. Each value in the map is a Callback Object that describes a request that may be initiated by the API provider and the expected responses.

properties.name: deprecated
properties.desc: Declares this operation to be deprecated. Consumers SHOULD refrain from usage of the declared operation. Default value is false.

properties.name: security
properties.desc: A declaration of which security mechanisms can be used for this operation. The list of values includes alternative security requirement objects that can be used. Only one of the security requirement objects need to be satisfied to authorize a request. To make security optional, an empty security requirement ({}) can be included in the array. This definition overrides any declared top-level security. To remove a top-level security declaration, an empty array can be used.

properties.name: servers
properties.desc: An alternative server array to service this operation. If an alternative server object is specified at the Path Item Object or Root level, it will be overridden by this value.

name: ExternalDocumentationObject
description: Allows referencing an external resource for extended documentation.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description of the target documentation. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: url
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The URL for the target documentation. Value MUST be in the format of a URL.

name: ParameterObject
description: Describes a single operation parameter.

properties.name: name
properties.desc:
REQUIRED. The name of the parameter. Parameter names are case sensitive.
  • If in is "path", the name field MUST correspond to a template expression occurring within the path field in the Paths Object. See Path Templating for further information.
  • If in is "header" and the name field is "Accept", "Content-Type" or "Authorization", the parameter definition SHALL be ignored.
  • For all other cases, the name corresponds to the parameter name used by the in property.

properties.name: in
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The location of the parameter. Possible values are "query", "header", "path" or "cookie".

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A brief description of the parameter. This could contain examples of use. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: required
properties.desc: Determines whether this parameter is mandatory. If the parameter location is "path", this property is REQUIRED and its value MUST be true. Otherwise, the property MAY be included and its default value is false.

properties.name: deprecated
properties.desc: Specifies that a parameter is deprecated and SHOULD be transitioned out of usage. Default value is false.

properties.name: allowEmptyValue
properties.desc: Sets the ability to pass empty-valued parameters. This is valid only for query parameters and allows sending a parameter with an empty value. Default value is false. If style is used, and if behavior is n/a (cannot be serialized), the value of allowEmptyValue SHALL be ignored. Use of this property is NOT RECOMMENDED, as it is likely to be removed in a later revision.

name: RequestBodyObject
description: Describes a single request body.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A brief description of the request body. This could contain examples of use. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: content
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The content of the request body. The key is a media type or media type range and the value describes it. For requests that match multiple keys, only the most specific key is applicable. e.g. text/plain overrides text/*

properties.name: required
properties.desc: Determines if the request body is required in the request. Defaults to false.

name: MediaTypeObject
description: Each Media Type Object provides schema and examples for the media type identified by its key.

properties.name: schema
properties.desc: The schema defining the content of the request, response, or parameter.

properties.name: example
properties.desc: Example of the media type. The example object SHOULD be in the correct format as specified by the media type. The example field is mutually exclusive of the examples field. Furthermore, if referencing a schema which contains an example, the example value SHALL override the example provided by the schema.

properties.name: examples
properties.desc: Examples of the media type. Each example object SHOULD match the media type and specified schema if present. The examples field is mutually exclusive of the example field. Furthermore, if referencing a schema which contains an example, the examples value SHALL override the example provided by the schema.

properties.name: encoding
properties.desc: A map between a property name and its encoding information. The key, being the property name, MUST exist in the schema as a property. The encoding object SHALL only apply to requestBody objects when the media type is multipart or application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

name: EncodingObject
description: A single encoding definition applied to a single schema property.

properties.name: contentType
properties.desc: The Content-Type for encoding a specific property. Default value depends on the property type: for string with format being binary – application/octet-stream; for other primitive types – text/plain; for object - application/json; for array – the default is defined based on the inner type. The value can be a specific media type (e.g. application/json), a wildcard media type (e.g. image/*), or a comma-separated list of the two types.

properties.name: headers
properties.desc: A map allowing additional information to be provided as headers, for example Content-Disposition. Content-Type is described separately and SHALL be ignored in this section. This property SHALL be ignored if the request body media type is not a multipart.

properties.name: style
properties.desc: Describes how a specific property value will be serialized depending on its type. See Parameter Object for details on the style property. The behavior follows the same values as query parameters, including default values. This property SHALL be ignored if the request body media type is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

properties.name: explode
properties.desc: When this is true, property values of type array or object generate separate parameters for each value of the array, or key-value-pair of the map. For other types of properties this property has no effect. When style is form, the default value is true. For all other styles, the default value is false. This property SHALL be ignored if the request body media type is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

properties.name: allowReserved
properties.desc: Determines whether the parameter value SHOULD allow reserved characters, as defined by RFC3986 :/?#[]@!$&'()*+,;= to be included without percent-encoding. The default value is false. This property SHALL be ignored if the request body media type is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

name: ResponsesObject
description:
A container for the expected responses of an operation.
The container maps a HTTP response code to the expected response.

properties.name: default
properties.desc: The documentation of responses other than the ones declared for specific HTTP response codes. Use this field to cover undeclared responses. A Reference Object can link to a response that the OpenAPI Object's components/responses section defines.

name: ResponseObject
description: Describes a single response from an API Operation, including design-time, static links to operations based on the response.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: REQUIRED. A short description of the response. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: headers
properties.desc: Maps a header name to its definition. RFC7230 states header names are case insensitive. If a response header is defined with the name "Content-Type", it SHALL be ignored.

properties.name: content
properties.desc: A map containing descriptions of potential response payloads. The key is a media type or media type range and the value describes it. For responses that match multiple keys, only the most specific key is applicable. e.g. text/plain overrides text/*

properties.name: links
properties.desc: A map of operations links that can be followed from the response. The key of the map is a short name for the link, following the naming constraints of the names for Component Objects.

name: CallbackObject
description: A map of possible out-of band callbacks related to the parent operation. Each value in the map is a Path Item Object that describes a set of requests that may be initiated by the API provider and the expected responses. The key value used to identify the path item object is an expression, evaluated at runtime, that identifies a URL to use for the callback operation.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: A Path Item Object used to define a callback request and expected responses. A complete example is available.

name: ExampleObject
description: This object MAY be extended with Specification Extensions.

properties.name: summary
properties.desc: Short description for the example.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: Long description for the example. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: value
properties.desc: Embedded literal example. The value field and externalValue field are mutually exclusive. To represent examples of media types that cannot naturally represented in JSON or YAML, use a string value to contain the example, escaping where necessary.

properties.name: externalValue
properties.desc: A URL that points to the literal example. This provides the capability to reference examples that cannot easily be included in JSON or YAML documents. The value field and externalValue field are mutually exclusive.

name: LinkObject
description: The Link object represents a possible design-time link for a response. The presence of a link does not guarantee the caller's ability to successfully invoke it, rather it provides a known relationship and traversal mechanism between responses and other operations.

properties.name: operationRef
properties.desc: A relative or absolute URI reference to an OAS operation. This field is mutually exclusive of the operationId field, and MUST point to an Operation Object. Relative operationRef values MAY be used to locate an existing Operation Object in the OpenAPI definition.

properties.name: operationId
properties.desc: The name of an existing, resolvable OAS operation, as defined with a unique operationId. This field is mutually exclusive of the operationRef field.

properties.name: parameters
properties.desc: A map representing parameters to pass to an operation as specified with operationId or identified via operationRef. The key is the parameter name to be used, whereas the value can be a constant or an expression to be evaluated and passed to the linked operation. The parameter name can be qualified using the parameter location [{in}.]{name} for operations that use the same parameter name in different locations (e.g. path.id).

properties.name: requestBody
properties.desc: A literal value or {expression} to use as a request body when calling the target operation.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A description of the link. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: server
properties.desc: A server object to be used by the target operation.

name: HeaderObject
description: The Header Object follows the structure of the Parameter Object with the following changes:

properties.name: name
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The name of the tag.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description for the tag. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this tag.

name: TagObject
description: Adds metadata to a single tag that is used by the Operation Object. It is not mandatory to have a Tag Object per tag defined in the Operation Object instances.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The name of the tag.

properties.name: description
properties.desc: A short description for the tag. CommonMark syntax MAY be used for rich text representation.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this tag.

name: ReferenceObject
description: A simple object to allow referencing other components in the specification, internally and externally.

properties.name: $ref
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The reference string.

name: SchemaObject
description: The Schema Object allows the definition of input and output data types. These types can be objects, but also primitives and arrays. This object is an extended subset of the JSON Schema Specification Wright Draft 00.

properties.name: nullable
properties.desc: A true value adds "null" to the allowed type specified by the type keyword, only if type is explicitly defined within the same Schema Object. Other Schema Object constraints retain their defined behavior, and therefore may disallow the use of null as a value. A false value leaves the specified or default type unmodified. The default value is false.

properties.name: discriminator
properties.desc: Adds support for polymorphism. The discriminator is an object name that is used to differentiate between other schemas which may satisfy the payload description. See Composition and Inheritance for more details.

properties.name: readOnly
properties.desc: Relevant only for Schema "properties" definitions. Declares the property as "read only". This means that it MAY be sent as part of a response but SHOULD NOT be sent as part of the request. If the property is marked as readOnly being true and is in the required list, the required will take effect on the response only. A property MUST NOT be marked as both readOnly and writeOnly being true. Default value is false.

properties.name: writeOnly
properties.desc: Relevant only for Schema "properties" definitions. Declares the property as "write only". Therefore, it MAY be sent as part of a request but SHOULD NOT be sent as part of the response. If the property is marked as writeOnly being true and is in the required list, the required will take effect on the request only. A property MUST NOT be marked as both readOnly and writeOnly being true. Default value is false.

properties.name: xml
properties.desc: This MAY be used only on properties schemas. It has no effect on root schemas. Adds additional metadata to describe the XML representation of this property.

properties.name: externalDocs
properties.desc: Additional external documentation for this schema.

properties.name: example
properties.desc: A free-form property to include an example of an instance for this schema. To represent examples that cannot be naturally represented in JSON or YAML, a string value can be used to contain the example with escaping where necessary.

properties.name: deprecated
properties.desc: Specifies that a schema is deprecated and SHOULD be transitioned out of usage. Default value is false.

name: DiscriminatorObject
description: When request bodies or response payloads may be one of a number of different schemas, a discriminator object can be used to aid in serialization, deserialization, and validation. The discriminator is a specific object in a schema which is used to inform the consumer of the specification of an alternative schema based on the value associated with it.

properties.name: propertyName
properties.desc: REQUIRED. The name of the property in the payload that will hold the discriminator value.

properties.name: mapping
properties.desc: An object to hold mappings between payload values and schema names or references.

name: XMLObject
description: A metadata object that allows for more fine-tuned XML model definitions.

properties.name: name
properties.desc: Replaces the name of the element/attribute used for the described schema property. When defined within items, it will affect the name of the individual XML elements within the list. When defined alongside type being array (outside the items), it will affect the wrapping element and only if wrapped is true. If wrapped is false, it will be ignored.

properties.name: namespace
properties.desc: The URI of the namespace definition. Value MUST be in the form of an absolute URI.

properties.name: prefix
properties.desc: The prefix to be used for the name.

properties.name: attribute
properties.desc: Declares whether the property definition translates to an attribute instead of an element. Default value is false.

properties.name: wrapped
properties.desc: MAY be used only for an array definition. Signifies whether the array is wrapped (for example, <books><book/><book/></books>) or unwrapped (<book/><book/>). Default value is false. The definition takes effect only when defined alongside type being array (outside the items).

name: SecuritySchemeObject
description: Defines a security scheme that can be used by the operations. Supported schemes are HTTP authentication, an API key (either as a header, a cookie parameter or as a query parameter), OAuth2's common flows (implicit, password, client credentials and authorization code) as defined in RFC6749, and OpenID Connect Discovery.

properties.name: type
properties.desc: Any

properties.name: description
properties.desc: Any

properties.name: name
properties.desc: apiKey

properties.name: in
properties.desc: apiKey

properties.name: scheme
properties.desc: http

properties.name: bearerFormat
properties.desc: http ("bearer")

properties.name: flows
properties.desc: oauth2

properties.name: openIdConnectUrl
properties.desc: openIdConnect

name: OAuthFlowsObject
description: Allows configuration of the supported OAuth Flows.

properties.name: implicit
properties.desc: Configuration for the OAuth Implicit flow

properties.name: password
properties.desc: Configuration for the OAuth Resource Owner Password flow

properties.name: clientCredentials
properties.desc: Configuration for the OAuth Client Credentials flow. Previously called application in OpenAPI 2.0.

properties.name: authorizationCode
properties.desc: Configuration for the OAuth Authorization Code flow. Previously called accessCode in OpenAPI 2.0.

name: OAuthFlowObject
description: Configuration details for a supported OAuth Flow

properties.name: authorizationUrl
properties.desc: oauth2 ("implicit", "authorizationCode")

properties.name: tokenUrl
properties.desc: oauth2 ("password", "clientCredentials", "authorizationCode")

properties.name: refreshUrl
properties.desc: oauth2

properties.name: scopes
properties.desc: oauth2

name: SecurityRequirementObject
description: Lists the required security schemes to execute this operation. The name used for each property MUST correspond to a security scheme declared in the Security Schemes under the Components Object.

properties.name: [key: string]
properties.desc: Each name MUST correspond to a security scheme which is declared in the Security Schemes under the Components Object. If the security scheme is of type "oauth2" or "openIdConnect", then the value is a list of scope names required for the execution, and the list MAY be empty if authorization does not require a specified scope. For other security scheme types, the array MUST be empty.
